questions.text: Which of the following radioisotopes is used in a PET-CT scan?
questions.solution:
18F-FDG is the radioisotope used in a PET-CT scan.

Positron emission tomography - CT (PET-CT):

  • PET imaging is based on the detection of an injected positron-emitting radioactive tracer.
  • It relies on the coincidence detection of the annihilation photons (γ), which are released when a positron combines with an electron.
  • A glucose analog called FDG (fluorodeoxyglucose) is used in PET imaging. FDG is taken up by metabolically active cells, where it undergoes phosphorylation to form FDG-6-phosphate. Unlike glucose, FDG-6-phosphate cannot undergo further metabolism and becomes trapped within the cell.
  • The trapped FDG-6-phosphate is detected by the PET scanner.
  • The combination of PET imaging with CT (PET-CT) combines the metabolic information (PET) with the cross-sectional anatomic information (CT).

Indications of PET-CT:

  • PET-CT is used in oncology imaging to detect malignant cells as they demonstrate increased glucose metabolism relative to normal tissues.
  • It is indicated for the differentiation of a malignant from a benign lesion.
  • It is indicated in tumor staging and evaluation of tumor recurrence.

Technique:

  • The patient must fast for 4-6 hrs prior to imaging.
  • Strenuous activity must be avoided prior to imaging and after radioisotope injection to avoid physiological muscle FDG uptake.
  • Bladder catheterization or voiding prior to imaging, bowel opacification, or IV contrast medium is optional.
  • Before injecting FDG, the blood glucose level should be measured. It should be < 150 mg/dL. Good blood glucose control is essential as FDG uptake is competitively inhibited by glucose.
  • Imaging is started 60 minutes following FDG injection.
  • An enhanced whole-body CT study is done, which takes 60-70 seconds. Following this, a whole-body PET imaging, takes about 30-45 minutes to complete.

questions.text: An exclusively breastfed newborn was brought with vomiting and diarrhea that developed since birth. On examination, the baby is jaundiced, hypotonic, and has hepatomegaly. Urine was positive for Benedict's test, blood glucose was low and erythrocyte galactose-1-phosphate was elevated. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of an exclusively breastfed infant with vomiting, diarrhea, jaundice, hypotonia, and hepatomegaly with elevated erythrocyte galactose-1-phosphate is suggestive of classical galactosemia.

Classical galactosemia is an autosomal recessive disorder. The enzyme deficient here is galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase (GALT). Normally, newborns receive up to 40% of their intake as lactose (glucose + galactose). Without GALT, the infant can't metabolize galactose 1-phosphate which accumulates and causes injury to the kidney, liver, and brain.

Clinical features include vomiting, hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, jaundice, congenital cataracts, aminoaciduria, and failure to thrive. There is an increased incidence of Escherichia coli neonatal sepsis. Long-term complications include speech delays, learning impairment, motor dysfunction, and hypergonadotrophic hypogonadism (in females)

The presence of galactose in urine (Positive benedict's test), elevated blood galactose, and elevated erythrocyte galactose-1-phosphate help in confirming the diagnosis.

Treatment is a galactose-free diet. Supportive therapy and prevention of complications is important.

Other options:

Option A: Fructosuria is due to the deficiency of fructokinase. There are no symptoms except for the benign excretion of fructose in urine. Inherited as autosomal recessive. 

Option B: Von Gierke's disease is due to glucose-6-phosphatase or translocase deficiency. It is a glycogen storage disorder (Type I).  They may develop hypoglycemia and lactic acidosis in the neonatal period, but hepatomegaly usually develops at 3–4 months. They may have doll-like facies, short stature, and a protuberant abdomen. Hyperuricemia, the elevation of triglycerides, low-density lipoproteins, and phospholipids are seen.

Option D: Hereditary fructose intolerance is due to a deficiency of fructose 1, 6-bisphosphate aldolase (aldolase B). Patients are healthy and symptom-free until fructose or sucrose is ingested. Clinical manifestations may include jaundice, hepatomegaly, vomiting, lethargy, irritability, and convulsions

questions.text: Which of the following sites is most commonly involved in Crohn’s disease?
questions.solution:
The most commonly affected site in Crohn's disease is the terminal ileum. 

Other commonly affected sites in Crohn's disease include the small intestine and the colon. Although it can affect any part of the GI tract from mouth to anus, the rectum is usually spared.

On the other hand, the rectum is almost always involved in ulcerative colitis.

questions.text: During the evaluation of a patient with recurrent urinary tract infections, the following urographic finding was observed. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the inferolateral displacement of the opacified lower pole due to an obstructed (and unopacified) upper pole. This is called the drooping lily sign and is observed in patients with a duplicated collecting system. 

This condition is characterized by an incomplete fusion of upper and lower pole moieties resulting in a variety of complete or incomplete duplications of the collecting system.

Duplex collecting systems may also be complicated by vesicoureteric reflux, obstruction, or ureterocoele.

questions.text: A 33-year-old lady complained of increased sensitivity to certain odors. Which of the following nerves is unlikely to be involved?
questions.solution:
The hypoglossal nerve is a purely motor cranial nerve and is not involved in olfaction.

The other three cranial nerves— trigeminal, glossopharyngeal, and vagus nerves—are mixed cranial nerves and contribute to olfaction.

Vagal nerve stimulation modifies the electrical activity of the olfactory bulb.

questions.text: In judicial hanging , the knot is placed at____________
questions.solution:
In judicial hanging ,the knot is placed at angle of jaw.

Judicial hanging

  • Face of the person is covered with dark mask ,he is made to stand on a platform above trapdoors ,which open downwards when blot is drawn.
  • Rope is looped around the neck and person is allowed to drop for 5-7 meters according to weight, age and build.
  • Sudden stop usually causes fracture dislocation at level C-2, C-3 or C-3  C-4 vertebra and rupture of brainstem between pons and medulla (hangman fracture).
  • Death is instantaneous but heartbeat may continue for 15-20 minutes and spasmodic muscle jerking may occur for considerable time.
  • Asphyxial signs are not seen in correctly performed judicial hangings.

questions.text: Q. You are working as an intern in the ENT department. A child is brought to you with complaints of noisy breathing. On examination, you notice biphasic stridor in the child. Which of the following conditions can be ruled out in this child?
questions.solution:
Laryngomalacia causes inspiratory stridor. Hence, it is not considered as part of the differential diagnosis for biphasic stridor.

Stridor is noisy respiration produced by turbulent airflow through the narrowed air passages. It may be heard during inspiration, expiration, or both.

  • Inspiratory stridor is often produced in obstructive lesions of supraglottis or pharynx, e.g. laryngomalacia or retropharyngeal abscess.
  • Biphasic stridor is seen in lesions of the glottis, subglottis, and cervical trachea, e.g. laryngeal papillomas, vocal cord paralysis, and subglottic stenosis.
  • Expiratory stridor is produced in lesions of thoracic trachea, primary and secondary bronchi, e.g. bronchial foreign body, and tracheal stenosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of the quadruple screening test?
questions.solution:
Inhibin B is not a component assayed under the quad-screening test. Dimeric inhibin-A is evaluated in this screening test.

Quadruple testing is done in the second trimester between 15-21 weeks of gestation. It comprises:

  • Maternal serum AFP
  • Human chorionic gonadotropin
  • Unconjugated estriol (E3)
  • Dimeric inhibin A

questions.text: A young patient presents to the dermatology OPD with a history of itchy hypopigmented patches over her chest for 6 months. A KOH mount is prepared with the skin scraping sample, which on microscopy reveals a characteristic appearance as shown in the image. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture and the KOH mount preparation showing the spaghetti and meatball appearance suggest pityriasis versicolor.

Pityriasis Versicolor is a chronic superficial infection of the stratum corneum caused by Malassezia globosa and Malassezia furfur. The most common site involves the neck, chest, back, and upper arms. The lesions often appear as hypopigmented areas.

The KOH mount reveals fungal hyphae that are short and thick (like spaghetti or banana) and many variously sized spores (like meatballs or grapes) referred to as spaghetti and meatballs or bananas and grapes appearance.

Treatment includes topical azoles or terbinafine for 2 weeks.

The image below shows the hypopigmented lesions of P. versicolor over the chest.

questions.text: A 33-year old P3L3 woman complained of intermenstrual bleeding. On speculum examination, a polypoid lesion was visualized in the cervix, which was confirmed with the ultrasound shown below. What is the most appropriate management?

choices.text: Wait and watch with serial sonograms

questions.solution:
The above ultrasound image shows the presence of an endocervical polyp. The most appropriate treatment is avulsion using ring forceps.

Endocervical polyps are overgrowths of benign endocervical stroma covered by mucinous columnar epithelium. They appear as single, red, smooth elongated masses arising from the endocervical canal. Polyps range from a few millimeters to 2-3 cm in size and are more frequently seen in multiparas.

Endocervical polyps are usually asymptomatic, but also cause intermenstrual or postcoital bleeding or vaginal discharge. They are identified by inspection during a pelvic examination or during transvaginal sonography if they are located higher up.

They are typically benign. Premalignant or malignant transformation is rare. However, cervical cancer can also present as polypoid masses and can mimic these benign lesions.

Treatment:

  • Asymptomatic polyps usually don't need any intervention
  • Symptomatic:
    • Removal with ring forceps: The polyp is twisted repeatedly about the base of its stalk to strangulate its feeding vessels. With a repeated twisting, the base will narrow and avulse.
    • Removal with punch biopsy forceps for smaller polyps
    • Electrosurgical excision or hysteroscopic removal for polyps with thick stalks

After the removal of polyps, the base can be cauterized to prevent bleeding and recurrence rate. Every excised polyp should be sent for further histological examination to rule out malignancy.

questions.text: Antigen binding to MHC class I activates which of the following cells?
questions.solution:
Antigen binding to major histocompatibility complex (MHC) class I activates cytotoxic T cells.

The major histocompatibility complex (MHC), is a genetic locus that encodes a group of antigens. The MHC molecules also bind peptide antigens and present them to the T cells. The human MHC is called the human leukocyte antigen (HLA) complex.

The MHC class I proteins present their antigens to CD8 T cells (cytotoxic T cells). The antigens bound to MHC class II proteins activate the CD4 T cells( T helper cells). There is no cross recognition between the T cells and MHC classes. This is known as MHC restriction. For example, a CD4 T cell would recognize an antigen presented by a macrophage only if it's bound to MHC class II molecules. 

Other options:

Option B - B cells interact with an antigen based on the immunoglobulin surface receptors on the B cell. The receptor along with the antigen is embodied and degraded and the peptides produced are returned to the cell surface. It is then bound to the MHC class II molecules present on the cell surface. This is then recognized by CD4 T cells. Ultimately, the B cells are stimulated to proliferate and differentiate into plasma cells which secrete antibodies. 

Option C - Natural killer (NK) cells are granular lymphocytes that confer innate immunity by protecting against viruses and intracellular pathogens. 

Option D - T helper cells are responsible for the production of cytokines which activate the humoral and cell-mediated branches of immunity. These cells will recognize only those antigens that are presented along with MCH class II molecules on APC such as macrophages and B lymphocytes.

Related Pearl: MHC Classes I and II

MHC Class I

MHC Class II

Expressed on all nucleated cells and platelets

Mainly expressed on cells that present ingested antigens and respond to T-cell help (macrophages, B lymphocytes, and dendritic cells).

Consist of a polymorphic α, or heavy, chain linked noncovalently to the nonpolymorphic protein called β2-microglobulin

Heterodimer consisting of a noncovalently associated α chain and β chain, both of which are polymorphic.

The α chains are encoded by three genes, designated HLA-A, HLA-B, and HLA-C

Encoded in a region called HLA-D, which has three subregions: HLA-DP, HLA-DQ, and HLA-DR.

Display peptides that are derived from proteins, such as viral and tumor antigens

Present antigens that are internalized into vesicles, and are typically derived from extracellular microbes and soluble proteins

Peptide-class I complexes are recognized by CD8+ T cells, which function as CTLs.

Class II-peptide complex is recognized by CD4+ T cells

questions.text: A young man presented to the emergency department one hour after spilling hot oil on his hands while cooking. On examination, multiple blisters are present on his right hand. The injuries are extremely painful when touched with gloves and capillary refilling is normal.  Which layers of skin are involved in this case?
questions.solution:
This patient with multiple blisters, tenderness over the injured skin, and normal capillary refilling time has second-degree superficial burns. The layers of skin involved here are the epidermis and papillary dermis (the upper part of the dermis).

According to the depth and the extent of tissue damage, burn injuries can be classified as follows:

  • First-degree burns: In this, there is damage to the epidermis. These injuries are extremely painful but do not blister. They have a normal capillary refilling time.
  • Second-degree burns (partial-thickness burns): In this, there is damage to the epidermis and dermis. Depending on the extent of the dermal involvement, they can further be divided into superficial or deep.
    • Superficial partial-thickness burns: They involve the epidermis and upper part of the dermis (papillary). These injuries are red, moist, and extremely painful and blisters are present. The capillary return is visible when the injured skin is blanched.
    • Deep partial-thickness burns: They involve the epidermis and the deeper dermis. These injuries are less painful and some sensation is preserved. The capillaries do not blanch on pressure.
  • Third-degree burns:  In this degree, there is damage to the epidermis, dermis, and subcutaneous tissue. The injuries have a hard leathery feel with the absence of sensation.
  • Fourth-degree burns: In this degree, there is damage to the underlying soft tissues.

questions.text: A child presents with lesions as shown in the image below. He also complained of decreased vision at night. Which of the following dose of vitamin A prophylaxis given to children under the vitamin A distribution scheme in India could have prevented this condition?

choices.text: 2,00,000 IU  given yearly between the ages 1-6 years
1,00,000 IU  given yearly between the ages 1-6 years
1,00,000 IU  given 6-monthly between the ages 1-6 years
2,00,000 IU given 6-monthly between the ages 1-6 years

questions.solution:
The image above showing phrynoderma along with the history of decreased vision at the night suggests a likely diagnosis of vitamin A deficiency. Under the vitamin-A distribution scheme in India, 200,000 IU of vitamin A are given orally at 6-monthly intervals between the ages of 1 to 6 years.

Vitamin A deficiency is a major preventable cause of blindness in children. It can lead to mucocutaneous disease and result in various ocular complications, including blindness. The earliest sign of vitamin A deficiency is defective dark adaptation and night blindness (nyctalopia). Xerosis and scaling are commonly present in cutaneous findings. Phrynoderma, which is characterized by the presence of keratotic follicular papules over anterolateral thighs and posterolateral upper arms is also seen.

Treatment is done by administering 50,000–2,00,000 IU of daily vitamin A supplementation until clinical signs and symptoms resolve and serum retinol levels normalize. 

The image below shows a Bitot's spot(due to Vitamin A deficiency) seen as a foamy appearance on the surface of the conjunctiva.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents to the ER with colicky abdominal pain. His mother tells you that he refuses to walk due to knee pain. On examination, palpable purpura is noted. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation of palpable purpura, colicky abdominal pain, and arthritis, point towards a diagnosis of Henoch Schonlein purpura (HSP) also known as IgA vasculitis.

It is a small vessel vasculitis that occurs due to IgA immune complex deposition within the wall of the blood vessels. It is commonly seen in children and is characterized by:

  • Palpable purpura without thrombocytopenia and coagulopathy.
  • Arthralgia- commonly affecting hip, knee, or ankle joints.
  • Abdominal pain
  • Glomerulonephritis: proteinuria, microscopic hematuria, RBC casts in urine.

The skin biopsy will show small vessel vasculitis, with IgA and C3 deposition in the affected organs by immunofluorescence.

Option B: Hemolytic uremic syndrome is characterized by a triad of microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and acute kidney injury.

Option C: Juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA) is characterized by fever of at least 2 weeks duration associated with arthritis, evanescent erythematous rash, hepatosplenomegaly, generalized lymphadenopathy, and serositis.

Option D: Patients with IgA nephropathy or Berger's disease present with gross hematuria, often associated with a preceding or ongoing viral infection of the upper respiratory tract (synpharyngitic presentation).

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about port wine stain:
questions.solution:
Port wine stain is a congenital low-flow vascular malformation that does not fade away with time.

Port wine stains are congenital lesions that may occur anywhere in the body. Visually they appear as partially or completely blanchable, pink to red or reddish brown patches.

Commonly they occur as isolated skin lesions but in rare cases, they are part of certain complex syndromes.

This lesion is associated with syndromes such as Sturge-Weber syndrome and occult spinal dysraphism. Port-wine stain occurring in the distribution of the trigeminal nerve is associated with Sturge-Weber syndrome.

Features of port wine stain:

  • Does not fade with time
  • Special form of nevus flammeus
  • Tends to grow during childhood
  • Thicken the skin surface

questions.text: From the following epidemic curve, identify the type of epidemic depicted.
questions.solution:
Point-source epidemic is depicted in the given image.

In the epidemic curve for a point-source epidemic, there is a sharp rise and fall of the curve with no secondary waves. It tends to be explosive as all the cases are clustered in a narrow period of time and they occur within one incubation period of the disease.

An epidemic is an occurrence in a community or region of cases of an illness that is clearly in excess of normal expectancy.

Types

Common source epidemics

  • Single exposure or 'point source' epidemics
  • Multiple or continuous exposure epidemics

Propagated epidemics

  • Person to person
  • Arthropod vector
  • Animal reservoir

Slow or modern epidemics

  • Non-communicable diseases

questions.text: An infant who is diagnosed with congenital hypothyroidism presents with the following hernia. Which of the following statements is false regarding the management of this child?

choices.text: The hernia may spontaneously resolve by 2 years of age
Surgical repair is indicated if the hernia persists for more than 5 years of age
Strangulation is a common complication associated with this type of hernia
Mayo’s procedure or mesh repair can be done for this hernia

questions.solution:
The given clinical history of congenital hypothyroidism and the image showing a mass protruding out of the umbilicus is indicative of an umbilical hernia. Obstruction and strangulation are uncommon below the age of 3 years.

Congenital hypothyroidism is a condition caused by an embryological defect in the thyroid gland or thyroid hormone synthesis.

Congenital hypothyroidism is commonly associated with other features such as:

  • Myxedematous facies
  • Large fontanelles
  • Macroglossia
  • Umbilical hernia
  • Hypotonia

Mayo’s operation is done for an umbilical hernia. Indications for surgery in umbilical hernia are:

  • Defect size >2cm
  • Persisting beyond 5 years
  • Progressively enlarging after 2 years of age (usually regresses spontaneously by 2 years of age)
  • Symptomatic
  • Strangulated

questions.text: Preoperative fasting recommendation is _________

choices.text: 2 hours for clear liquids in adults
2 hours for breast milk in infants

questions.solution:
Preoperative fasting recommendation is 2 hours for liquids in adults.

Recommended Preoperative Fasting period:

  • For neonates and infants:
    • 2 hours for clear fluids
    • 4 hours for breast milk
    • 6 hours for solids and infant formula
  • For all above 1 year of age:
    • 2 hours for clear fluids
    • 6 hours for a light meal
    • 8 hours if the meal contains fried, fatty food

Preoperative fasting is intended to reduce the risk of pulmonary aspiration.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the given dose-response curve:

choices.text: Drug B is the most potent
Drug B is the most efficacious
Drug C is more efficacious than drug D
Drug B is more efficacious than drug A

questions.solution:
The more the curve is to the left, the more is its potency. Hence drug B is the most potent on the given dose-response curve (DRC).

Potency

  • It is defined as the amount of drug needed to produce a given response.
  • The more the curve is on the left side, the more is its potency.
  • Hence in the given DRC drug B is most potent and drug D is the least potent.

Efficacy

  • It is defined as the maximum effect produced by the drug and is determined by the peak of the curve.

Hence in the given DRC, drug B has the least efficacy, and drugs A, C & D are equally efficacious.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is normal peristalsis not seen?
questions.solution:
Achalasia cardia does not show normal peristalsis.

Manometric features of achalasia cardia are as follows:

  • Incomplete lower esophageal sphincter relaxation
  • Aperistalsis of the esophageal body
  • Elevated LES pressure

Diffuse esophageal spasm is characterized by simultaneous multi-peaked contractions of the esophagus. The contractions are spontaneous and may be of abnormally high amplitude (>120 mmHg) or long duration. Intermittent normal peristalsis is seen.

Nutcracker esophagus is characterized by high amplitude (≥180 mmHg) contractions with an increased mean duration. The peristaltic sequence is normal.

Hypertensive lower esophageal sphincter is characterized by elevated LES pressure (≥26 mmHg). Normal peristalsis is seen in the body of the esophagus.

Esophageal carcinoma will not have any issues with the motility or peristalsis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient presented after an episode of acute gastroenteritis and was infused with fluids. A while later, after fluid infusion, his heart rate rose to 122 bpm and he complained of palpitations. The presence of tachycardia can be explained by which of the following mechanisms?
questions.solution:
The presence of tachycardia can be explained by the Bainbridge reflex.

It is a compensatory cardiac reflex where there is an increase in the heart rate in response to raised atrial stretch.

In fluid overload states, commonly after excessive fluid infusion, there is distension of the atria due to increased blood volume. This distension activates the atrial stretch receptors which transmit the afferent signals to the medulla via the vagus nerve. The efferent signals are then transmitted back through vagal and sympathetic nerves. This leads to an increase in the strength of contraction of the heart and tachycardia. This reflex helps in preventing excess accumulation of blood in the atria, veins, and in the pulmonary circulation.

Other options - 

Option A: Bezold-Jarisch reflex is due to the activation of chemosensitive vagal C fibers in the cardiopulmonary region. They can be elicited after administering certain irritants like capsaicin or serotonin. It can also be activated during myocardial infarction and on exposure to radioactive dyes during coronary angiography. This reflex is characterized by profound brady­cardia, hypotension, and a brief period of apnea followed by rapid shallow breathing. 

Option B: Pulmonary chemoreflex is due to the stimulation of the J-receptors (C receptors/juxta-pulmonary capillary receptors) which are stimulated when there is hyperinflation of the lung. This produces reflex apnea followed by a rapid increase in breathing rate, bradycardia, and hypotension.

Option D: Cushing's reflex is seen when the intracranial pressure is raised where the blood supply to ventrolateral medulla neurons is compromised. The local hypoxia and hypercapnia stimulate the neurons producing hypertension, bradycardia, and irregular respiration.

*Note: Bainbridge reflex causes tachycardia, whereas all the other mentioned reflexes predominately cause bradycardia.

questions.text: The sign given below is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The given image has the characteristic wrist sign i.e. the distal phalange of the first and fifth fingers of the hand overlaps when wrapped around the opposite wrist. This is seen in Marfan's syndrome. This happens as their fingers and hands are long and slender and have a spider-like appearance (arachnodactyly). 

Marfan's syndrome is an inherited connective tissue disorder that is caused by a mutation in a gene that codes for an extracellular matrix protein-fibrillin-1 (FBN1). The FBN1 locus is on the long arm of chromosome 15. It is a clinical diagnosis based on skeletal, cardiovascular, and ocular manifestations. 

Skeletal manifestations: 

  • Overgrowth of long bones (dolichostenomelia) with an arm span to height ratio of more than 1.05
  • Pectus carinatum or pectus excavatum
  • Long and slender fingers (arachnodactyly), contracture of fingers (camptodactyly)
  • Malar hypoplasia
  • Joint laxity 

Cardiovascular manifestations:

  • Thickened atrioventricular valves, valvular prolapse (mitral regurgitation) 
  • Aortic valve dysfunction due to aortic root aneurysm
  • Aortic dissection and rupture due to cystic medial necrosis of the aorta

Ocular manifestations:

  • ectopia lentis
  • myopia
  • flat cornea
  • retinal detachments
  • early cataracts and glaucoma

Other systemic manifestations: 

  • thoracic scoliosis
  • spontaneous pneumothorax
  • striae atrophicae in the skin

Image (a) shows Walker-Murdoch (wrist) sign - the ability to join the thumb and fifth finger around the wrist. Image (b) shows Steinberg (thumb) sign - thumb tip extends from the palm of the hand in a closed fist 

 

Diagnosis is based on criteria depending on the family history, aortic root X score, ectopia lentis, mitral valve prolapse, and presence of FBN1 mutation.

Other options:

Option B: Ehler Danlos syndrome is characterized by hyperextensible skin and hypermobile joints. However, the wrist sign is not a characteristic of EDS.

Option C: Osteogenesis imperfecta is characterized by a decrease in bone mineral density. Hence, the bones are very fragile limiting the physical activity of the patient.

Option D: Pseudoxanthoma elasticum is characterized by abnormal deposition of calcium in the elastic fibers of skin, eyes, and vessels.

questions.text: The following conditions are commonly associated with Cushing’s syndrome except
questions.solution:
Cushing’s syndrome leads to impaired glucose tolerance and hyperglycemia.

  • Excess mineralocorticoid production may lead to hypertension and hypokalemia
  • Frank psychosis may also be observed in Cushing’s syndrome

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of MEN2 syndrome?
questions.solution:
Pituitary adenoma is not a characteristic feature of the symptom complex of MEN2 and its variants, but it is observed in MEN1 syndrome.

Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia (MEN) refers to a group of inherited syndromes including various benign and malignant tumors of endocrine glands. There are four types - MEN 1-4. They have an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance and can also be sporadic.

Related Pearl: MEN 1 Syndrome Features

Chromosome 11q13 / MEN1 gene

Also known as Wermer’s syndrome

Characteristic tumors seen in:

  • Parathyroid adenoma – 90 % - Most common overall
  • Entero pancreatic tumors - Most common functioning tumor is gastrinoma (most common site is duodenum)
  • Pituitary adenoma – Most common is prolactinoma
  • Mnemonic – Par Pan Pit – in decreasing order of frequency

Associated tumors are:

  • Angiofibroma
  • Collagenomas
  • Adrenal cortical tumors
  • Lipoma
  • Neuroendocrine tumors - gastric, thymic, lungs
  • Meningioma
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Carcinoid tumors, usually of the foregut

Related Pearl: MEN 2 Syndrome Features

MEN 2A

  • Known as Sipple’s syndrome
  • Chromosome 10 / RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Parathyroid adenoma (10–25%)

MEN 2B

  • Known commonly as MEN 3
  • Chromosome 10/ RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (>90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Other associated abnormalities include: (40–50%)
      • Mucosal neuromas
      • Marfanoid habitus
      • Medullated corneal nerve fibers
      • Megacolon

questions.text: A 15 year old girl comes with itchy lesions on her elbows as shown. Her family history is positive for asthma. What could be the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This is a case of atopic dermatitis.

Atopic dermatitis (AD) is the cutaneous expression of the atopic state, characterised by a family history of asthma, allergic rhinitis or eczema.

A characteristic defect is impaired epidermal barrier. In many patients a mutation in gene encoding filaggrin, a structural protein in the stratum corneum is responsible. The lesions are distributed in the flexural aspects.(as shown in the image).

Patients may display many immunoregulatory abnormalities, including increased IgE synthesis, increased serum IgE levels, delayed type hypersensitivity reactions.

Clinical features:

  • Pruritus and scratching
  • Course marked by exacerbations and remissions
  • Lesions typical of eczematous dermatitis
  • Personal or family history of atopy (asthma, allergic rhinitis, food allergy, eczema)
  • Clinical course more than 6 weeks
  • Lichenification of skin

questions.text: Pseudodementia is associated with which of the following conditions
questions.solution:
Pseudodementia is a condition characterized by cognitive and functional impairment secondary to depression.

  • Dementia is defined as a disease process, which is marked by progressive cognitive impairment in clear consciousness. Ex: Dementia in Alzheimer's disease.
  • Pseudodementia occurs in depressed people who complain of impaired memory but, in fact, have a depressive disorder.

The following table shows differentiating clinical features between dementia and pseudodementia:

Dementia

Pseudodementia

Clinical Course and History

 

Onset can be dated only within broad limits

Onset can be dated precisely

Long duration and slow progression of symptoms

Short duration and rapid progression of symptoms

Usually, there is no history of previous psychiatric dysfunction

There is a history of previous psychiatric dysfunction.

Family is not aware of the patient's dysfunction and severity

Family is aware of the patient's dysfunction and severity

Complaints and clinical behaviour

The patients complain little of cognitive loss, and the complaints are often vague

The patients complain much of cognitive loss, and the complaints are detailed.

Usually labile affect

  

Severe depression on examination

Disability is concealed by the patient

Disability is emphasized by the patient

Patient highlights accomplishments

Patient highlights failures

They struggle to perform simple tasks and rely on notes or calendars etc.

They make little effort to perform even simple tasks

Social skills are often retained

Loss of social skills often early and prominent
Behaviour is compatible with the severity of cognitive dysfunction Behaviour is incongruent with the severity of cognitive dysfunction
Nocturnal accentuation of dysfunction common Nocturnal accentuation of dysfunction uncommon

Clinical Features Related to Memory, Cognitive, and Intellectual Dysfunctions

Patient makes errors on cognitive examination

‘Do not know’ answers are more frequent

Attention and concentration usually faulty

 Attention and concentration often well preserved

Memory loss for recent events usually more severe than for remote events

  

Memory loss for recent and remote events usually severe

Memory gaps for specific periods unusual. Confabulation may be present.

  Memory gaps are usually present. Confabulation is rare.

questions.text: A woman is planning a trip to Morocco, which is endemic for yellow fever. As per travel regulations, she receives the yellow fever vaccine. After how many days following vaccination is she eligible to travel?
questions.solution:
This woman is eligible to travel to the endemic area 10 days after being vaccinated for yellow fever. This period is required for the majority of vaccine recipients to develop immunity.

The 17D vaccine is a live attenuated vaccine, administered subcutaneously.  It is valid for a lifetime beginning 10 days after vaccination.  The incubation period of yellow fever is 3–6 days. Unvaccinated people are required to remain quarantined for 6 days (maximum period of incubation).
